item.title: Gondi and its Orthography
item.description:
Gondi and its Writing system

Author: IDCL editor

This article is also available in Telugu Tamil and Malayalam languages.

Gondi is a Dravidian language spoken in the Indian states of Madhya Pradesh, Telangana, Maharashtra, and Chhattisgarh. It belongs to the South Central Dravidian branch of the Dravidian language family and classified as an endangered language. It has over 2.98 million autochthonous speakers, but the language, and it’s dialects, are diminishing. Gondi is a dialect-centric language, sometimes they are pertained as Gondi languages. The primal dialects of this language include Dorla,¬†Koya,¬†Madiya,¬†Muria, and Raj Gond.

Writing system

Several scripts are utilised to write Gondi language. These are associated with the dialect of Gondi. A wide view about Gondi being a strictly oral language overturned when the Gunjala Gondi orthography re-emerged with the aid of¬†researchers from the University of Hyderabad. In addition to this,¬†Munshi Mangal Singh Masaram excogitated a script for Gondi in 1928. Besides, the language also wonts Telugu and Devanagri orthographies.

All scripts of Gondi have UNICODE encoding.

Gunjala Gondi Script

Your device may not render this script, for that you can see the images provided under

item.title: Suriyani Malayalam
item.description:
Suriyani Malayalam

Author: IDCL Editor

This article is available in Malayalam language .

Suriyani Malayalam is a liturgical variant of the Malayalam language written with a modified version of the East Syriac script. It is also known as Karshoni or Syriac Malayalam. Suriyani Malayalam is related to the traditional Christian community of Kerala, known by the names Nasranis and Suriyanis. It follows the grammar of the Malayalam language and uses a lot of loan words from East Syriac. It continued as a prominent variety of Malayalam unto the 19th Century.

The Script

Type of writing system: Abjad The direction of writing: left-right in horizontal lines

Suriyani Alphabet Table

Suriyani Latin equivalent Suriyani Latin equivalent

item.title: Malayalam Language General Proficiency Test
item.description:
Document

‡¥µ‡¥£‡¥ï‡µç‡¥ï‡¥Ç | ‡¥®‡¥Æ‡¥∏‡µç‡¥ï‡¥æ‡¥∞‡¥Ç

This is a free online Malayalam proficiency test.
This online level test will give you an approximate indication of your Malayalam language level

  • There will be a total of 20 Multiple choice questions
  • You can either choose an option or leave it and press the submit button to move to the next question.
  • At the end of the test, your score will be displayed along with your Malayalam Language level (ML).

Note that ML5(Advanced) and ML6(Proficient) levels are not available in this test

For enquiries, reach out to us through dclprogramme@gmail.com

item.title: IDCL
item.description:
Author: IDCL Editor

Welcome to the Initiative on Dravidian Culture & Languages.

Initiative on Dravidian Culture and Languages (IDCL) aims to preserve and promote the linguistic and cultural diversity on India and beyond. The project has been established to improve the availability of resources and dedicate digital platforms for the enrichment of languages and cultures.

The importance of language preservation has become a necessity in this age of globalisation. More than 3000 languages in the world are considered as endangered. This means that about half of the world’s linguistic identity is currently under threat. Linguistically diverse countries like India are struggling to conserve their indigenous languages. Languages spoken by the majority are pushing minority languages into extinction, and the lack of effective government programmes are pushing these underprivileged communities into an identity crisis.

In recent years, many interested individuals have come forward to take effective actions to protect their linguistic and cultural identity. Various digital platforms became a boon for these volunteers. However, due to a lack of resources and affordable tools, it has been very difficult for the to work in such projects.

So let’s see what we can do to preserve and promote these languages.

1. Resource gathering

Documentation can be in text, image, video or audio format. Recording the speech of native speakers is an effective way to document under-resourced languages. The documentation in image format can be converted to text for further analysis. If possible, gathering resources from archives and converting them to various digital formats becomes very helpful for language development.

2. Preparing Educational materials

Educational materials can be prepared in two ways ;

  1. full documentation, which includes grammar, vocabulary, orthography etc.

  2. preparing educational materials for beginners or translating books (sciences, social studies etc.) from other languages to the target language.

  3. Developing digital tools such as software, translators and learning apps. While this process requires a lot of resources and work, the end-user receives a lot of benefits. The accessibility and affordability of such tools make the conservation of the target language much easier.

Volunteering

Individual projects

This require the collection of data, conversion of data into usable formats, preparation of digital materials and publishing them.

Group projects

A group of volunteers contributing to a project. This method reduces the workload, increases the overall performance, reduces the time taken to publish the final material.

For enquiries, reach out to us through dclprogramme@gmail.com

Follow us on
Instagram | Youtube | Facebook
